input: What role does T-cell count play in severe human adenovirus type 55 (HAdV-55) infection?
actual_output: According to the provided passages, a lower T-cell count may be a risk factor for severe HAdV-55 infection. In a study, three out of five patients with severe disease had relatively low T-cell counts when admitted, suggesting that they may have been immunocompromised. In contrast, the only patient who recovered from severe infection had higher T-cell counts. This implies that T-cells play a crucial role in the clearance of HAdV-55 viremia and survival of the host. A higher T-cell count may be associated with better outcomes in HAdV-55 infection.
expected_output: The T-cell count plays a crucial role in severe human adenovirus type 55 (HAdV-55) infection, as patients with severe disease may have low T-cell counts. In the study mentioned, the only patient who recovered from severe infection had higher T-cell counts, suggesting that a lower T-cell count may be a risk factor for severe HAdV-55 infection.

Chen et al. reported that, in the acute phase of HAdV-55 infection, patients with severe disease may have high levels of dendritic cells and Th17 cells . In our study, the only patient who recovered from severe infection had higher T-cell counts. Three of the five patients had relatively low T-cell counts when admitted. Yet, because of their low avidity, the ability of these T cells to lyse infected cells, and thereby to protect against viral infection, may be poor . During the replication process, the cells release antiviral factors and cytokines that alter local airway inflammation and airway niche . actual_output: Based on the provided passages, MVO stands for Multi-Verse Optimizer, which is a type of optimization algorithm used to enhance the performance of Adaptive Neuro-Fuzzy Inference System (ANFIS) models. Specifically, it is mentioned in one of the passages that the MVO algorithm was used to improve the ANFIS model to forecast oil consumption in two countries.

input: What have sero-surveys of MERS virus found?
actual_output: Sero-surveys of MERS virus have found no sign of MERS-CoV antibodies among 2,400 sera from patients visiting a hospital in Jeddah from 2010 through 2012, prior to the description of MERS-CoV. Similarly, no sign of prior MERS-CoV infection was detected among a small sample of 130 healthy blood donors from another hospital in Jeddah. However, among 226 slaughterhouse workers, eight were positive by IFA, although those sera could not be confirmed by virus neutralization. In contrast, seropositive dromedary camels (DCs) have been found throughout the Arabian Peninsula and parts of Africa, indicating that they may host MERS-CoV infection. No detectable neutralizing antibody against MERS-CoV has been found in other animals tested, including sheep, cows, pigs, horses, and others.
expected_output: Sero-surveys of MERS virus found no sign of MERS-CoV antibodies among patients visiting hospitals in Jeddah from 2010 through 2012, nor any sign of prior MERS-CoV infection among healthy blood donors and only 10% of strongly seropositive Canary Island in a sero-survey of livestock. They did, however, find 15 sera collected in 2012 to 2013 from 10,009 people in 13 KSA provinces contained MERS-CoV antibodies, with significantly higher proportions occurring in camel shepherds and slaughterhouse workers.

input: What genome sequence was available for this study?
actual_output: Based on the provided passages, it appears that the study utilized whole genome data retrieved from GenBank, which included ITR sequences ranging from 116 to 209 bases in length. Additionally, the study used the 3D7 reference genome for aligning Illumina read data. The study also generated consensus genome assemblies, which were submitted to GenBank. The specific genome sequence used for the study is not explicitly stated, but it is likely that it was a collection of clinical isolates with whole genome short-read sequencing data.
expected_output: The genome sequences for the study were available in NCBI's GenBank database, and the Illumina read data was submitted to NCBI's Short Read Archive.
retrieval_context: ['Passage: All sequences are available in GenBank from which whole genome data were retrieved and aligned, and ITR sequences extracted. This resulted in a data set of ITR sequences ranging from 116 to 209 bases, as lengths were variable among the types. A subset of sequences spanning the first 1-66 bases that included the conserved HAdV viral replication sequence motifs were selected for detailed analysis.', "Passage: All consensus genome assemblies generated as part of this project were submitted to NCBI's GenBank database . Illumina read data was submitted to NCBI's Short Read Archive under Trace Identifiers SRR513075, SRR513078, SRR513080, SRR513086-87, SRR513092, and SRR527699-726.", "Passage: For the full collection of clinical isolates that had whole genome short-read sequencing data , reads were aligned to the 3D7 reference genome using bowtie2 . Samples with less than 10 million reads mapping to the reference were excluded, as samples with less than this amount had reduced coverage across the genome. Bam files were processed according to GATK's Best Practices documentation . Joint SNP calling was done using Haplotype Caller . Because clinical samples may be polyclonal , diploid calls were initially allowed, followed by calling the major allele at positions with heterozygous calls. If the major allele was", "Passage: We used the ''Insignia'' program , a bioinformatics on line tool developed in the Center for Bioinformatics and Computational Biology, University of Maryland to choose a specific DNA or RNA ''signature'' for targeted viruses. Comparative sequence analysis of the complete genomes was performed using mVISTA . Multiple nucleotide sequence alignments were then created to visualize the most conserved genome areas using MEGA4 .", 'Passage: For the 143 HMPV genomes, we checked sequence conservation at transcriptional control regions, at the termini of each gene, as well as the lengths of intergenic sequences between gene boundaries. The SH-G and G-L intergenic regions were the longest, up to 125 nt and to 190 nt, respectively. Consensus nucleotides at the putative start and end regions flanking the ORF of the viral genes are shown in Fig. 1 . The gene-start and -end regions of N', "Passage: Of the 19 participating studies, 13 were prospective cohort studies, 5 were RCTs, and 1 was a quasiexperimental study . The target sample size for studies ranged from 255-10,000. Actual sample recruitment at the time of interview ranged from 205 for the Community Aging in Place -Advancing Better Living for Elders study with older adults aging in place to 2528 for the Alzheimer's Disease Anti-Inflammatory Prevention Trial . Though", 'Passage: A total of 39,329 records were identified by the PubMed/MEDLINE search , and 39,305 articles met the study inclusion criteria after 24 records had been excluded .
